entry.title: Elon Musk's Grok AI Will 'Remove Her Clothes' In Public, On X
entry.summary: Elon Musk’s AI bot is undressing women on X.

entry.title: Man Who Hacked Disney With Malicious AI Tool Pleads Guilty
entry.summary: A hacker who tricked people into downloading malware using AI image generation tools plead guilty to two felony counts.

entry.title: GlobalX, Airline for Trump’s Deportations, Hacked
entry.summary: Hackers say they have obtained what they say are passenger lists for GlobalX flights from January to this month. The data appears to include people who have been deported.

entry.title: Dimension 126 Contains Strangely Twisted Shapes, Mathematicians Prove
entry.summary: A new proof represents the culmination of a 65-year-old story about anomalous shapes in special dimensions. The post Dimension 126 Contains Strangely Twisted Shapes, Mathematicians Prove first appeared on Quanta Magazine

entry.title: 100,000 People Are Using a Telegram Bot That Makes AI Cumshot Videos of Anyone
entry.summary: An open AI video generation model that was released last month is now being used by thousands of people to generate nonconsensual sexual videos of real people.

entry.title: Mr. Deepfakes, the Biggest Deepfake Porn Site on the Internet, Says It’s Shutting Down for Good
entry.summary: The biggest site for nonconsensual deepfake porn on the internet says it’s shutting down and not coming back.

entry.title: The Signal Clone the Trump Admin Uses Was Hacked
entry.summary: TeleMessage, a company that makes a modified version of Signal that archives messages for government agencies, was hacked.

entry.title: These Tardigrades Have Tiny Tattoos
entry.summary: Tardigrades, tiny microscopic animals, woke up from suspended animation with body art.

entry.title: U.S. Denies Picking Bombing Targets From Random Twitter Accounts
entry.summary: An anonymous OSINT sleuth mis-identified a quarry as an underground Houthi base. Days later, the Pentagon allegedly struck the site and killed eight people.

entry.title: Your Children’s Children Will Die in Our Factories
entry.summary: The small, pathetic technofeudalist dystopian vision of Howard Lutnick and the Trump administration.

entry.title: Behind the Blog: The News Hits Different
entry.summary: This week, we discuss eyebrow-raising apps, more media mess, and lovingly gazing at AI slop.

entry.title: Mike Waltz Accidentally Reveals Obscure App the Government Is Using to Archive Signal Messages
entry.summary: A photograph of Trump administration official Mike Waltz's phone shows him using an unofficial version of Signal designed to archive messages during a cabinet meeting.

entry.title: Army Will Seek Right to Repair Clauses in All Its Contracts
entry.summary: A recent memo detailed a future where soldiers can repair their own equipment.

entry.title: Polygon Acquired by Porn Mogul Who Co-Founded Brazzers
entry.summary: Before he founded Valnet, Hassan Youssef started one of the biggest porn sites on the internet.

entry.title: Mark Zuckerberg Thinks You Don't Have Enough Friends and His Chatbots Are the Answer
entry.summary: The CEO of Meta says "the average American has fewer than three friends, fewer than three people they would consider friends. And the average person has demand for meaningfully more.”

entry.title: Recession Indicator: Bookings for the German Tour Bus in Los Angeles Are Down 30%
entry.summary: Donald Trump: "Tourism is way up."

entry.title: Will AI Ever Understand Language Like Humans?
entry.summary: AI may sound like a human, but that doesn’t mean that AI learns like a human. In this episode, Ellie Pavlick explains why understanding how LLMs can process language could unlock deeper insights into both AI and the human mind. The post Will AI Ever Understand Language Like Humans? first appeared on Quanta Magazine

entry.title: Science, Promise and Peril in the Age of AI
entry.summary: An exploration of how artificial intelligence is changing what it means to do science and math, and what it means to be a scientist. The post Science, Promise and Peril in the Age of AI first appeared on Quanta Magazine

author.name: Michael Moyer, Ben Brubaker, John Pavlus, Mark Belan, Jordana Cepelewicz, Yasemin Saplakoglu, Gregory Barber, Elise Cutts and Emily Buder

entry.title: Where Do Scientists Think This Is All Going?
entry.summary: We asked some of the world’s foremost experts an impossible question. Amazingly, they answered. The post Where Do Scientists Think This Is All Going? first appeared on Quanta Magazine

entry.title: What Happens When AI Starts To Ask the Questions?
entry.summary: Technology has forever served as science’s toolbox. But now that AI is being used to develop questions and methods as well, some scientists wonder what their role is going to become. The post What Happens When AI Starts To Ask the Questions? first appeared on Quanta Magazine

entry.title: Reports of the Death of California High-Speed Rail Have Been Greatly Exaggerated
entry.summary: Building a high-speed rail between Los Angeles and San Francisco was never going to be easy — but the critics who write it off are missing the real source of the project’s struggles.

entry.title: Does AI Progress Have a Speed Limit?
entry.summary: A conversation about the factors that might slow down the pace of AI development, what could happen next, and whether we’ll be able to see it coming.

entry.title: Does Abundance Start at Home?
entry.summary: Kelsey Piper and Jasmine Sun talk about microschools, whether localism is the enemy of Abundance, and why Chinese bureaucrats are like Growth PMs.
